results.title: JFK: Director's cut. Beyond JFK: the question of the conspiracy
results.creator_credit: Oliver Stone, A. Kitman Ho and Ixtlan Corporation
results.brief_description: Starring Kevin Costner, Joe Pesci, Tommy Lee Jones, and Gary Oldman, JFK also features an extensive gallery of appearances by acclaimed actors including Ed Asner, Walter Matthau, Jack Lemmon and Donald Sutherland. This exclusive release has an exta 17 minutes of new footage added, providing more excitement, intrigue and insight into Jim Garrison’s turbulent investigation of President John F. Kennedy’s assassination. Also included on this tape is “Beyond JFK: The question of the conspiracy” a ninety-minute documentary that re-examines the issues raised by the film, featuring interviews with the people who were involved in the Garrison investigation plus astonishing eyewitness accounts. Includes Jim Garrison’s last recorded interview before he died.

results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “The Global Economy”.
This first episode of the Open Learning economics course examines the changing international relations arising from the increasingly transglobal nature of financial markets. The first part of the episode examines general issues of international trade while the second focuses on the automobile industry in Australia and explores some of the pressures, issues and dynamics involved in restructuring a national industry to maximise competitiveness in international markets.

results.title: Fixed vs floating exchange rates (NP)
results.creator_credit: Ashley Schwall-Kearney, Craig Saunders, ABC-TV (Australia), Monash University and Open Learning Agency of Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode number 7 of Series “The Global Economy”.
This episode of the Open Learning Economics course examines the history of exchange rates in contemporary capitalism. After World War II, exchange rates were fixed to the value of the US dollar which in turn was fixed to the price of gold. Over the 1960’s, however, the rise of speculation on international currencies saw exchange rates fluctuate at such an unstable rate that in 1971 the US government decided to allow its currency to be determined by the market rather than be affixed to gold prices. Since 1973 the value of currency has been determined by market forces rather than by being fixed to government determined rates. Using the example of the 1970s Oil Crisis, a panel of economists argue that market-determined exchange rates allow for greater flexibility.

Episode number 13 of Series “The Global Economy”.
This episode of The Global Economy focuses on the changing nature of the world’s various economies by considering two examples: China as a developing economy (Passing on development) and the USA (Continual change, continual growth) with its dominance of the computer software industry. A panel of economists discuss the nature of change in the local market place and the effects this creates globally.

results.title: The Environment (NP)
results.creator_credit: Ashley Schwall-Kearney, Craig Saunders, ABC-TV (Australia), Monash University and Open Learning Agency of Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode number 12 of Series “The Global Economy”.
This episode of the Open Learning Economics course looks at the way the international economic community is tackling the issue of environmental protection. Since the late 1970s there has been a growing concern, especially by communities in wealthier nations, over the high environmental cost of unrestricted economic development. Developing countries, however, have argued that trade restrictions predicated on environmental law offer unfair economic advantages to richer nations. In the first half of the program we look at the example of the Mexican tuna industry which has come under fire because of the destruction of dolphin life. However when the United States attempted to place an embargo on Mexican tuna, the General Agreement on Tarrifs and Trade (GATT) ruled that this was contrary to the principles of Free Trade. In the second half we look at the destruction of Europe’s Rhine River by industrial pollution. The panel of economists examining both issues discuss some of the implications for trade if environmental law becomes institutionalised in the global economy.

results.creator_credit: Ashley Schwall-Kearney, Craig Saunders, ABC-TV (Australia), Monash University and Open Learning Agency of Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode number 11 of Series “The Global Economy”.
This episode of the Open Learning Economics course examines the development of free market economic systems in the former communist states of Eastern Europe. The first episode looks at the emergence of liberal capitalism in Russia. The episode examines the benefits of opening Russia’s markets to the rest of the globe though it acknowledges that this embracement of capitalism, at an accelerated pace, has the potential to create devastating divisions based on wealth. The second episode looks at the success of capitalism in Poland which turned away from State Socialism in the early 1980s. In interviews with economists and Polish business people we are given an insight into some of the difficulties involved in dismantling a socialist economic system and replacing it with a market open to the international capitalist economy.

results.title: Doctor De Soto and 5 other funny stories
results.creator_credit: Michael Sporn, Morton Schindel and Weston Woods Studios
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Children’s circle”.
A collection of animated short stories for children. “Doctor De Soto” by William Steig. The kind-hearted mouse Doctor De Soto is a dentist. He and his wife find a very clever way to treat a crafty fox, who comes to them with a sore tooth and secret thoughts of eating them after the job is done. This outstanding cartoon was nominated for an Academy Award for Best Animated Short Film. “Patrick” by Quentin Blake. When Patrick plays his fiddle, the countryside comes alive with vibrant colour and motion. “The Hat” by Tomi Ungerer. Penniless Benito finds good fortune when he comes upon a magic black hat with which he can perform fantastic feats. “Smile for Auntie” by Diane Paterson. Silly Auntie sings, dances, makes funny faces, stands on her head - anything to get the baby to smile! “The Foolish Frog” by Pete And Charles Seeger. Folk singer Pete Seeger plays and sings this catchy song about the frog who fell in the mud, to the delightful drawings of Mioslav Jagr. “Leopold the See-through Crumb-picker” by James Flora. Leopold is invisible and devours every crumb he finds, creating havoc in the process. See what happens when a little girl befriends him.

This outstanding cartoon was nominated for an Academy Award for Best Animated Short Film. “Patrick” by Quentin Blake. When Patrick plays his fiddle, the countryside comes alive with vibrant colour and motion. “The Hat” by Tomi Ungerer. Penniless Benito finds good fortune when he comes upon a magic black hat with which he can perform fantastic feats. “Smile for Auntie” by Diane Paterson. Silly Auntie sings, dances, makes funny faces, stands on her head - anything to get the baby to smile! “The Foolish Frog” by Pete And Charles Seeger. Folk singer Pete Seeger plays and sings this catchy song about the frog who fell in the mud, to the delightful drawings of Mioslav Jagr. “Leopold the See-through Crumb-picker” by James Flora. Leopold is invisible and devours every crumb he finds, creating havoc in the process. See what happens when a little girl befriends him.

Where the wild things are is Maurice Sendak’s classic tale of Mischievous Max, who sails to where the wild things are and becomes their king. “The Nutshell Kids” features four delightful teaching poems set to music. “In the Night Kitchen” Little Mickey dreams of the kitchen at night where bakers bake cakes, dough aeroplanes fly and everyone dances to the deliciously syncopated music.

results.title: Asterix in Britain
results.creator_credit: Pino Van Lamsweerde, Yannik Piel, Dargaud Films and Gaumont-British Instructional
results.brief_description: The world-famous comic-strip character, that madcap Gaul, Asterix is brought to life in this animated feature. The battle skills of the Britons are undeniably the equal of Caesar’s Roman troops. However, they are handicapped by their habit of refusing to fight on weekends and leaving the battlefield promptly at five every afternoon in time for tea. Whilst the Britons are caught napping after dinner, the Romans win the war and overrun Britain. A plea from the English leader, Zebigboss, goes out to the mighty Asterix and his Roman-hating friend Obelix. Join all the familiar friends in this great adventure including Druid Getafix, Dogmatix, Chief Vitalstatistix, Cacofonix and many more. Based on the popular books by Goscinny and Underzo.

results.title: Madeline's Christmas
results.creator_credit: Stephen Martiniere, Ronald A Weinberg, Cinar and France Animation
results.brief_description: Madeline (the mischievous little heroine with a heart twice her size) and eleven of her friends experience a snowstorm and are confined indoors. But it’s Christmas so Madeline cares and cleans for her sneezing friends with many songs and cheer, reminding us all of the true spirit of Christmas - love and friendship. Based on the popular novels by Ludwig Bemelmans and narrated by Christopher Plummer.
